Are You Sure You Want To
You must go to Sultan Riau Mosque and take a photo there to get XP
You must go to Malay Traditional Hall and take a photo there to get XP
You must go to Raja Ali Hajis Tomb and take a photo there to get XP
Upload 4 photos of historical sites from Penyengat Island
Upload 4 photos of historical sites from Penyengat Island

The Malay Traditional Hall on Penyengat Island is a center for Malay communitys customary and cultural activities. This building serves as a gathering place for elders, community leaders, and residents to hold various customary ceremonies, deliberations, and other cultural activities. Its architecture reflects a distinctive Malay style with intricately carved wood full of philosophical meaning.
As a symbol of tradition preservation, the Malay Traditional Hall plays an important role in maintaining the continuity of noble values inherited from generation to generation. Di sini, various important decisions related to customs and community life are made through consensus.
In addition to its social and cultural functions, the Malay Traditional Hall also serves as an informal educational institution where younger generations are taught about Malay customs, history, and moral values. This makes the hall a vital cultural education institution.
The existence of the Malay Traditional Hall to this day demonstrates the commitment of the Penyengat Island community to preserve their cultural heritage. This hall is not only a silent witness to history but also continues to live as part of the communitys daily life.

Kursi Hill Cannon is a historical relic from the Riau-Lingga Sultanate era located on a hill on Penyengat Island. This cannon was formerly used as the primary defense tool against attacks from colonizers and pirates who often targeted the Sultanates waters.
The strategic position of the cannon facing the sea shows the importance of this location in the kingdoms defense system. In addition to its function as a weapon, this cannon also symbolizes the resistance and bravery of the Malay people in defending their homeland.
To this day, the Kursi Hill Cannon stands as a silent witness to struggle and is often visited by tourists who want to see firsthand the traces of local resistance history. Its location on top of a hill also offers beautiful panoramic views of the open sea.
The existence of this cannon reminds the younger generation of the importance of the spirit of struggle and patriotism in defending the sovereignty and honor of the nation.

The Physicians Building was one of the important facilities during the Riau-Lingga Sultanate era, used as a traditional healthcare service center. This building served as both a residence and practice space for royal physicians skilled in traditional Malay medicine, including herbal remedies, massage, and other natural therapies.
Built with a distinctive Malay architectural style combining Middle Eastern elements, this building proves that the public health system was organized even before the era of modernization. Physicians working in this building were usually chosen individuals with extensive knowledge of ancestral healing arts.
Today, the Physicians Building is an important part of historical and cultural preservation, showing that public health has been a primary concern since ancient times. Its well-preserved structure stands as a silent witness to the development of traditional medicine on Penyengat Island.
A visit to the Physicians Building provides insight into how the Malay community integrated traditional medicine into their daily lives, and appreciates the role of physicians in maintaining public health.

Engku Putris Tomb is the final resting place of Engku Putri Raja Hamidah, wife of Sultan Mahmud Syah III, who is widely known as a wise, influential woman who played a significant role in the development of Malay religion and culture. She is known for her role in the construction of the magnificent Sultan Riau Grand Mosque, and as an important figure in the preservation of Islamic values and customs.
Her tomb is located in the royal cemetery complex and is surrounded by protective structures adorned with distinctive Malay ornaments. This tomb is frequently visited by local communities and tourists who wish to learn more about this great woman in the history of the Riau-Lingga Sultanate.
Engku Putri symbolizes the strength of women in Malay history and is remembered for her enduring services. The existence of this tomb reminds us of the important role of women in Malay history and culture.
A pilgrimage to Engku Putris Tomb provides an opportunity to reflect on her contributions in shaping the cultural and spiritual identity of the Malay community on Penyengat Island.

Raja Ali Haji is one of the most influential intellectual figures in Malay cultural history. He was the author of the famous literary work ‚ÄúGurindam Dua Belas‚Äù, and the first figure to systematize the standard Malay language which later became the foundation of modern Indonesian.
His tomb is on Penyengat Island, where he spent much of his time writing and teaching. Raja Ali Haji was known for his dedication to advocating Malay identity through his writings and education. He also served as a royal advisor in literary affairs and policies.
The Raja Ali Haji tomb complex is now a highly respected cultural heritage site, frequently visited by researchers, students, and tourists. The existence of this tomb symbolizes the extraordinary intellectual wealth and literary heritage for the Indonesian nation.
Visiting this tomb pays homage to a figure who made significant contributions to the development of Malay language and literature, and strengthened the nations cultural identity.

Sultan Riau Grand Mosque is a historical mosque built in 1803 by Sultan Mahmud Syah III and the community of Penyengat Island. The uniqueness of this mosque lies in its building material, which uses a mixture of egg whites as a binder, reflecting innovative traditional construction techniques of its time.
This mosque is not only a place of worship but also a center for Islamic education and propagation. This predominantly yellow mosque has become the spiritual icon of Penyengat Island and a symbol of the Riau-Lingga Sultanates glory in spreading Islam. Here, religious knowledge, literature, and philosophy were taught by prominent scholars.
In addition, this mosque has unique architecture with 13 domes and 4 minarets symbolizing the number of prayer cycles in a day and night. Inside the mosque, there is also a handwritten Quran which is evidence of concern for science and education.
Sultan Riau Grand Mosque is now a cultural heritage site preserved by the government and local community, and an attractive religious tourist destination for visitors from various regions.

The Judges House was the official residence of the royal court official during the Riau-Lingga Sultanate era, who played an important role in administering Malay customary law. This house not only functioned as a residence but also as a courtroom for resolving various customary cases.
Its architecture reflects the grandeur of a Malay nobles house with a stilt house structure and wood carvings full of philosophy. This house symbolizes that a system of law and justice was orderly in effect at that time, with the judge as a central figure respected in society.
The existence of the Judges House shows that Malay civilization greatly valued justice and had implemented a neat and humane legal system long before colonial influence arrived. This house also served as a place for customary law education for the younger generation.
Visiting the Judges House provides an understanding of how the Malay community managed the judicial system and upheld law based on customary values and justice.
